commit_message:
Libvirt: Native LUKS decryption by QEMU

QEMU 2.6 and Libvirt 2.2.0 allow LUKS encrypted files, host block
devices and RBD volumes to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This spec
outlines the required changes to utilise this new functionality within
the Libvirt Nova virt driver and the possible benefits associated with
doing so.

Previously approved for Pike via I40a775e7c902de169900a7d53eadb47f8144ae81

Change-Id: Iade56845e954d815b7f59e42a0d06b3f08ea33af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/24/490824/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Libvirt: Native LUKS file and host device decryption by QEMU ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-qemu-native-luks QEMU 2.6 [1]_ and Libvirt 2.2.0 [2]_ allow LUKS files and block devices to be decrypted natively by QEMU. This spec outlines the required changes to utilise this new functionality within the Libvirt Nova virt driver and the possible benefits of doing so. Problem description =================== Nova currently supports the use of `LUKS` and `plain` dm-crypt encrypted volumes using the encryptor classes under `nova/volume/encryptors`. These frontend encryptor classes use `cryptsetup` to decrypt the encrypted volumes on the compute host. This creates a decrypted block device on the host that is then symlinked over the original volume path and attached to an instance. This use of `cryptsetup` and other external tools has been the source of many bugs and is an on-going maintenance overhead within Nova and os-brick. Use Cases --------- A user should be able to boot from or attach an encrypted LUKS volume of any file or host block device volume type to an instance without the use of host command-line utilities such as `cryptsetup`. Proposed change =============== The native LUKS support provided by QEMU 2.6 will be used when a given Libvirt compute host attempts to attach an encrypted volume with an encryption provider of `luks` and the required versions of QEMU and Libvirt present on the host. The required Libvirt disk encryption XML and passphrase secret will then be created, allowing QEMU to decrypt and attach the volume to the domain. If the required QEMU and LIbvirt versions are not present Nova will fallback to the current `LuksEncryptor` encryptor using `cryptsetup` to decrypt the volume. When detaching, the `LibvirtConfigGuestDisk` object associated with the volume will be inspected, using the presence of the encryption attribute to confirm which of the above approaches was used to decrypt the volume. If this attribute is None the original `cryptsetup` method of detaching the volume will be used, allowing encrypted volumes to still be detached across upgrades of Nova, QEMU or Libvirt. Alternatives ------------ * Continue to use the current `cryptsetup` frontend encryptors. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- * Decrypted block devices are no longer created on the host. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- This change should be transparent to existing users of `LuksEncryptor`. Users should continue to use this encryption provider as before, allowing Nova to decide when to use the native LUKS support offered by QEMU 2.6 or the original `cryptsetup` encryptors. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- The Libvirt virt driver will have a unique encryptor implementation outside of those Nova currently provides under `nova/volume/encryptors` or that were recently copied to os-brick under `os_brick/encryptors`. While this does mean that this implementation is not available to other virt drivers or OpenStack projects it is difficult to see how it would provide any benefit outside of the Libvirt virt driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: lyarwood Work Items ---------- * Extend the `nova/virt/libvirt/volumes/` block volume drivers to pass the encrypted properties of a volume to `LibvirtConfigGuestDisk`. * Extend the `LibvirtConfigGuestDisk` class to configure the encryption element of a disk device [3]_ and to also create the required Libvirt secret for the passphrase. * Only attempt to use QEMU to natively decrypt a given LUKS volume if the required QEMU and Libvirt versions are present on the compute host attaching the volume. * Otherwise fallback to the `cryptsetup` encryptors method of decrypting the volume. * Only use `cryptsetup` to detach LUKS volumes if the `LibvirtConfigGuestDisk` object associated with the volume is missing the encryption attribute. Dependencies ============ * QEMU 2.6 [1]_ * Libvirt 2.2.0 [2]_ Both are have already been released as part of the Ubuntu 17.04 [4]_ [5]_ [6]_ and Fedora 25 releases [7]_ [8]_ . The following devstack change now provides QEMU 2.8 and Libvirt 2.5.0 for Xenial based OpenStack CI jobs via the Ubuntu Cloud Archive allowing for this feature to be tested in the gate : Test using UCA for libvirt 2.5.0 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/451492/ Testing ======= * Unit tests. * Existing tempest tests should trigger the use of this new functionality assuming the required versions of Libvirt and QEMU are present. * Continue testing the fallback path using jobs that do not use UCA and thus do not provide the required QEMU and Libvirt versions. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== .. [1] http://wiki.qemu-project.org/ChangeLog/2.6#Block_devices_2 .. [2] https://libvirt.org/news-2016.html .. [3] https://libvirt.org/formatstorageencryption.html .. [4] https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/qemu .. [5] https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/libvirt .. [6] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Releases .. [7] https://apps.fedoraproject.org/packages/qemu .. [8] https://apps.fedoraproject.org/packages/libvirt History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

Fix prompts of mysql on installation doc

The installation doc for ubuntu shows MariaDB prompts, but the
previous lines shows the execution of mysql. So the prompts make
readers confused. This patch fixes these prompts.

commit_message:
add team structure doc

Document the how the team is designed to work.
Having the structure document will set the correct
expectations for everyone on the team.

Change-Id: Ie1130782bf93ae388cc902ce2b66017602754859
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/25/508325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Team Structure ============== Goals ----- * Increase developer focus, decrease distractions, interruptions, and time slicing. * Encourage collaborative development. The soft analysis over the past one to two years is that landing major new features and function in CI is difficult while being interrupted by a constant stream of issues. Each individual is siloed in their own work, feature or section of the production chain and there is very little time for thoughtful peer review and collaborative development. Team Structure ============== * The Ruck * The Rover * The Sprint Team The Ruck -------- One person per week will be on the front lines reporting failures found in CI. The Ruck & Rover switches roles in the second week of the sprint. * Primary focus is to watch CI, report bugs, improving debug documentation. * Does not participate in the sprint * Attends the OpenStack Program call * Responds to tq pings on #oooq / #tripleo * Reviews and improves documentation * Attends the release delivery meetings * Current release (mandatory) * Previous release (mandatory) * Attends meetings for the group where possible * Subscribe to tripleo-ci-ruck at redhat (link) The Rover --------- The primary backup for the Ruck. The Ruck should be catching all the issues in CI and passing off to the Rover for more in depth analysis or resolution of the bug. * Back up for the Ruck * Works of a bug queue, the Rover is not monitoring ci * Attends the sprint meetings, but is not responsible for any sprint work. * A secondary input for work is identified technical debt. * Helps to triage incoming gerrit reviews along with the TC. * Responds to pings on irc #oooq / #tripleo * If the Ruck is overwhelmed with any of the their responsibilities the Rover is the primary backup. The Sprint Team --------------- The team is defined at the beginning of the sprint based on availability. Members on the team should be as focused on the sprint epic as possible. A member of team should spend 80% of their time on sprint goals and 20% with any other duties like code review or incoming high priority bugs that the Rover can not manage alone. Sprint Structure ================ The goal of the sprint is to define a narrow and focused feature called an epic to work on in a collaborative way. Work not completed in the sprint will be added to the technical debt column of trello. **Note:** Each sprint needs a clear definition of done that is documented in the epic used for the sprint. Sprint Start ( Day 1 ) - 4 hours ---------------------- * Sprints are two weeks in length * A planning meeting is attended by the entire team including the Ruck and Rover * Review PTO * Assign Ruck and Rover positions * Review any meetings that need to be covered by the Ruck/Rover * Trello Board triage * Bug triage * The PM and UA will present a number of options for the sprint epic * Discuss the epic, lightly breaking each one down (30 minutes) * Vote on an epic * Break down the sprint epic into cards * Review each card * Each card must have a clear definition of done * As a group include as much detail in the card as to provide enough information for an engineer with little to no background with the task. Sprint End ( Day 10 ) - 4 hours ---------------------- * Retrospective ( 30 min ) * Document any technical debt left over from the sprint * Gerrit Review meeting ( 30 min ) * Ruck / Rover hand off ( 15 min ) * TripleO Community CI meeting ( 30 - 60 min ) * Office hours on irc ( 60 min ) Scrum meetings -------------- * Planning meeting, video conference ( 4 hours ) * Spring End, video and irc #oooq on freenode ( 4 hours ) * 2 live video conference meetings per week * sprint stand up ( 30 min ) * Other days, post status to etherpad * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-ci-squad-scrum Leaders ======= The team catalyst ----------------- * organize and plan sprint meetings * status emails The user advocate ----------------- * organize and prioritize the trello board for the sprint planning * monitor the board during hte sprint. * ensure the right work is being done. Where to find information about the sprint ========================================== Trello ------ A trello board will be used to organize work. The team is expected to keep the board and their cards updated on a daily basis. * https://trello.com/b/U1ITy0cu/tripleo-ci-squad Dashboards ---------- A number of dashboards are used to monitor the CI * http://cistatus.tripleo.org/ * https://dashboards.rdoproject.org/rdo-dev Team Notes ---------- * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-ci-squad-meeting

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-28 07:08:18.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/api/v3/test_groups.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/api/contrib/test_consistencygroups.py', 'cinder/group/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1192d49aa946f4e6d4efa1c78ce9453e3b86b3ea', 'message': 'Making reservations before group creation

The problem here was when we do reservation after creating group,
synchronization during quota_reserve() gets in_use value as 1 as
the group has already been created befre reserving & quota commit
updates groups in_use value as +1, hence making 2 for the first

Change-Id: If5f3cf75e39ed932028be7a2fb583c2576cb04bf
Closes-Bug: 1711381
(cherry picked from commit fc99c3cfdd54999518fd9aecdf4ec905366042b7)

commit_message:
Making reservations before group creation

The problem here was when we do reservation after creating group,
synchronization during quota_reserve() gets in_use value as 1 as
the group has already been created befre reserving & quota commit
updates groups in_use value as +1, hence making 2 for the first
time. So, reservations have been made before creating groups.

Change-Id: If5f3cf75e39ed932028be7a2fb583c2576cb04bf
Closes-Bug: 1711381
(cherry picked from commit fc99c3cfdd54999518fd9aecdf4ec905366042b7)

commit_message:
Specify 'become' to necessary tasks (general roles)

Add config_owner_user and config_owner_group to group_vars/all,
which is user and group of Kolla configuration files in /etc/kolla.

Add become to post-deploy playbook.

Add become to only neccesary tasks in roles:
- certificate
- common
- destroy
- haproxy
- mariadb
- memcached
- rabbitmq

Change-Id: I2aba745a6e3928c52642f64551470fd08cbfd058
Partial-Implements: blueprint ansible-specific-task-become
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/82/398682/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: become: true mode: "u=rwx,g=rwx,o=" mode: "u=rw,g=rw,o=" mode: "u=rw,g=rw,o=" mode: "u=rw,g=rw,o=" mode: "u=rw,g=rw,o=" - name: Ensuring config directories have correct owner and permission become: yes file: path: "{{ node_config_directory }}/{{ item }}" recurse: yes owner: "{{ config_owner_user }}" group: "{{ config_owner_group }}" with_items: - "keepalived" - "haproxy"

subject: Change MAAS DNS OCF to read IP from file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-29 02:14:47.000000000', 'files': ['hooks/hooks.py', 'hooks/utils.py', 'ocf/maas/dns', 'unit_tests/test_hacluster_utils.py', 'unit_tests/test_hacluster_hooks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-hacluster/commit/8e6e68161ac5cf762ee3553c41faae00e1e68419', 'message': "Change MAAS DNS OCF to read IP from file

The MAAS DNS ocf resource is created specifying the IP address
from the leader node. When the resource is moved to another node
the IP address is not updated because the DNS record already
points to the leader's IP address. This means that the DNS record
will never be updated with any other unit's IP address when the
resource is moved around the cluster.

The IP address to use for the DNS record should be stored in the
pacemaker resource as the configuration is the same across the
entire cluster. This change makes it so that the IP address that
should be bound is written to a file in /etc/maas_dns/$resource_name
and used by the ocf:maas:dns resource when managing the DNS
resource records.

Migration is handled by checking the current version of the MAAS
OCF resource file and determining if the OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE
(the name of the resource) is present in the file.

Change-Id: If4e07079dd66dac51cd77c2600106b9b562c2483
Closes-Bug: #1711476
(cherry picked from commit 8d81e415765d82ae8ee7640a5a89572d92b72b47)
"}]
commit_message:
Change MAAS DNS OCF to read IP from file

The MAAS DNS ocf resource is created specifying the IP address
from the leader node. When the resource is moved to another node
the IP address is not updated because the DNS record already
points to the leader's IP address. This means that the DNS record
will never be updated with any other unit's IP address when the
resource is moved around the cluster.

The IP address to use for the DNS record should be stored in the
pacemaker resource as the configuration is the same across the
entire cluster. This change makes it so that the IP address that
should be bound is written to a file in /etc/maas_dns/$resource_name
and used by the ocf:maas:dns resource when managing the DNS
resource records.

Migration is handled by checking the current version of the MAAS
OCF resource file and determining if the OCF_RESOURCE_INSTANCE
(the name of the resource) is present in the file.

Change-Id: If4e07079dd66dac51cd77c2600106b9b562c2483
Closes-Bug: #1711476
(cherry picked from commit 8d81e415765d82ae8ee7640a5a89572d92b72b47)

commit_message:
Replace root volume during rebuild

If the instance was booted from volume, then rebuild will only change
the image, but the instance will still boot from the original volume.

Create a new volume from the image then replace the old root volume
with it. In case of evacuation leave the root volume untouched.

Change-Id: If111fb66f361453a3c4c0caa50ebd639e5b4f1e6
Closes-Bug: #1482040
Closes-Bug: #1378689
Closes-Bug: #1474253

added_lines: from oslo_utils import units def _recreate_volume_based_bdm_from_image(self, context, image_meta, bdm): old_vol = self.volume_api.get(context, bdm.volume_id) vol_size = old_vol.get('size') vol_name = old_vol.get('name') display_description = old_vol.get('display_description') vol_type = old_vol.get('volume_type_id') metadata = old_vol.get('metadata') availability_zone = old_vol.get('availability_zone') image_min_disk = int(image_meta.min_disk or 0) * units.Gi image_size = int(image_meta.size or 0) dest_size = vol_size * units.Gi if image_size > dest_size: raise exception.FlavorDiskSmallerThanImage( flavor_size=dest_size, image_size=image_size) if image_min_disk > dest_size: raise exception.FlavorDiskSmallerThanMinDisk( flavor_size=dest_size, image_min_disk=image_min_disk) new_volume = self.volume_api.create(context, vol_size, vol_name, display_description, volume_type=vol_type, metadata=metadata, availability_zone=availability_zone, image_id=image_meta.id) self._await_block_device_map_created(context, new_volume['id']) LOG.debug('Created new root volume %s. Updating bdm.', new_volume['id']) bdm.volume_id = new_volume['id'] bdm.connection_info = None bdm.image_id = image_meta.id return bdm root_bdm = block_device.get_root_bdm(bdms) if root_bdm and root_bdm.is_volume: old_vol_id = root_bdm.volume_id new_root_bdm = self._recreate_volume_based_bdm_from_image( context, image_meta, root_bdm) if root_bdm.delete_on_termination: try: self.volume_api.delete(context, old_vol_id) except Exception as exc: LOG.warning(_LW('Failed to delete volume: ' '%(volume_id)s due to %(exc)s'), {'volume_id': root_bdm.volume_id, 'exc': exc}) bdms = list(block_device.get_bdms_to_connect( bdms, exclude_root_mapping=True)) bdms.insert(0, new_root_bdm)

Cleanup setup.cfg

and it is dependency of both testrepository
and os-testr
(probably was used by some tox wrapper script before)

commit_message:
PowerVM Driver Integration (Queens)

This blueprint continues the multi-release work of bringing the
out-of-tree PowerVM driver in-tree. This proposes the second phase
of in-tree driver functionality for queens.

Blueprint: powervm-nova-it-compute-driver

Change-Id: Ibf2c792e79447851c70f08e8a192756f2c1d6fdb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/61/503061/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== PowerVM Driver Integration - Queens ========================================== `<https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/powervm-nova-it-compute-driver>`_ The PowerVM driver has been developed out-of-tree, but with the intention to provide an in-tree implementation. Before it could be integrated in-tree, the Nova core teams provided several requirements that have since been met. The integration process began in Pike and a limited subset of functionality was implemented in-tree. This blueprint is part of a series that will work toward PowerVM driver integration and will expand on the functionality that was already implemented in the Pike release. Problem description =================== The PowerVM driver, which provides OpenStack enablement for AIX, IBM i and Linux virtual machines running on a PowerVM hypervisor, was proposed for integration into the main Nova tree and work to do so began in Pike. The out-of-tree driver has grown to contain a significant amount of function and maturity over the past few OpenStack releases, and the intention is to bring this driver in-tree. The work to drive towards full integration is expected to continue over multiple OpenStack releases. The first blueprint provided integration of the PowerVMLiveMigrateData object into Nova for the Ocata release, and laid out plans to incorporate minimal compute driver functionality incrementally. During Pike some of the basic driver functionality was introduced which is detailed below in the history section. This blueprint proposes the continuation of that work. The out-of-tree driver will be maintained, supported and extended as the in-tree driver is being integrated. For this phase, it is expected new code will first be proposed to the out-of-tree driver and then proposed in-tree. As the integration of the driver progresses further, that process shifts to all code being proposed in-tree. However, for any contribution (either in-tree or out-of-tree), the primary contributors of this blueprint will ensure the change is proposed to the other driver during this transition period. Use Cases --------- * A user should be able to deploy a glance-based image with basic networking (either SEA or OVS based) on a system with the PowerVM hypervisor. That image may be Linux (RHEL, SLES, Ubuntu, etc...), AIX or IBM i. They should be able to boot using config-drive and be able to attach vSCSI storage. Proposed change =============== The proposed change is to submit a series of patches to build on the basic functionality implemented in Pike. The new subset of driver code would support the following features. * Config-drive * SEA based networking * OVS based networking * vSCSI This does not bring the entirety of the PowerVM out-of-tree driver in-tree. There are other features that will not be implemented in-tree this release. Implementing the PowerVM driver in-tree is a long-term process that will continue through multiple Openstack releases. Alternatives ------------ None. The multi-release goal of integrating the PowerVM driver began in Pike, and other than abandoning this effort there is no alternative. Implementing the rest of the driver this release is too vast of a task and would take too much core reviewer time. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None. Integration has no performance effect on existing code paths. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers who wish to use the PowerVM driver will need to change the ``compute_driver`` in their conf to ``powervm.driver.PowerVMDriver``. The in-tree PowerVM driver implemented a very limited set of functionality in Pike. Deployers can install the nova-powervm out-of-tree driver to gain the additional functionality while the team works over multiple releases to integrate the driver. For this first phase of integration, there was no required configuration from the deployer beyond setting the ``compute_driver`` type. The driver will be documented in the hypervisor support matrix (along with its capabilities in-tree) and any additional configuration options will be documented. A new dependency on ``pypowervm`` was introduced in Ocata. This is a third-party, open-source library that allows its consumers to drive PowerVM virtualization. The pypowervm version requirement will be updated as needed throughout the Queens release. Developer impact ---------------- There are no changes to the driver API. The PowerVM driver will conform to the existing Nova API. Upgrade impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: efried esberglu edmondsw Other contributors: thorst Work Items ---------- * Add config-drive support * Add support for OVS-based networks * Add support for SEA-based networks * Add vSCSI support * Update PowerVM CI to stay up to date as new in-tree functionality as it is implemented. Dependencies ============ * `pypowervm`_ - third-party, open-source library that allows for control of the PowerVM platform. * PowerVM with `NovaLink`_ - PowerVM is the hypervisor, and the NovaLink is a Linux based Virtualization Management VM. The Novalink virtualization management VM is what allows the nova-compute process to run on the system itself. .. _`pypowervm`: http://github.com/powervm/pypowervm .. _`NovaLink`: https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/POWER8/p8eig/p8eig_kickoff.html Testing ======= All code paths run through the standard Tempest tests as part of our CI. The code will also include significant unit test. This code will come from the out-of-tree nova-powervm driver. The CI infrastructure will also continue to support the automated testing of the out-of-tree nova-powervm driver. PowerVM CI will post run results for both the out-of-tree and in-tree driver for all nova changesets. All logs will be publicly available. Non-gating votes will be provided by PowerVM CI. We have dedicated team members monitoring and supporting the CI. No new tests are required. The PowerVM driver is meant to conform to the Nova model. Documentation Impact ==================== We will continue to work with the ID team to update and create new documents for the PowerVM driver. The hypervisor support matrix will be updated as new functionality is implemented. References ========== * nova-powervm: * Overview: Out-of-tree Nova driver for PowerVM * Source: `<git://git.openstack.org/openstack/nova-powervm/>`_ * Bugs: `<https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova-powervm/>`_ * pypowervm * Overview: third-party, open-source module providing access to PowerVM hypervisor functionality. * Source: `<https://github.com/powervm/pypowervm/tree/develop>`_ * Bugs: `<https://bugs.launchpad.net/pypowervm/>`_ * networking-powervm: * Overview: Neutron ML2 mechanism driver and plugin supporting PowerVM's Shared Ethernet Adapter and (as of newton) SR-IOV virtual NIC. * Source: `<git://git.openstack.org/openstack/networking-powervm/>`_ * Bugs: `<https://bugs.launchpad.net/networking-powervm/>`_ * ceilometer-powervm: * Overview: Ceilometer collector for the PowerVM platform. Captures I/O, CPU and memory statistics. * Source: `<git://git.openstack.org/openstack/ceilometer-powervm/>`_ * Bugs: `<https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer-powervm/>`_ * Continuous Integration: * Overview: The CI server's configuration * CI Configuration: `<https://github.com/powervm/powervm-ci/tree/master>`_ History ======= Historically speaking, there have been a couple of other Power drivers. The first PowerVM driver was built on PowerVM and only worked with a component called IVM. The challenge with this was that it required the nova-compute to run on a separate server and SSH in to issue commands. It also did not integrate well with other OpenStack components. There was also the PowerVC OpenStack driver. This sat on top of PowerVC and was a clustered management model. Due to the push away from clustered management, this was not the approved management model for OpenStack Nova Compute. It was never pulled in-tree. This model is different, with core changes to the PowerVM hypervisor. It has been shipping in the field for a long period of time, and has products built on top of it. It also matches the development model of OpenStack Nova and has dedicated developers who have been working on it for multiple years. Lastly, Power systems also natively run Linux. For those wishing to use KVM on Power, the standard libvirt driver is also available. However, that support is limited to Linux based client virtual machines. A rough timeline is provided below. * November 2013: PowerVM IVM driver removed due to lack of CI and development. Also did not fit the direction of Nova core team to have the Nova compute process running on the system itself. * October 2014: `First commit`_ for new PowerVM driver built on NovaLink. * May 2015: Socialized the NovaLink based PowerVM driver at the summit. NovaLink changes the hypervisor itself to match the OpenStack model. All OpenStack code was developed from the start as open source. * October 2015: Liberty based out-of-tree nova-powervm driver released. All developed openly. Support for: * Lifecycle operations * Spawn from glance * Cinder FC support * Nova with networking-powervm agent * Live Migration * AIX and Linux VMs * DevStack * TaskFlow in its core to support graceful rollbacks of failed operations * January 2016: Continuous Integration environment live. * April 2016: nova-powervm driver updated for Mitaka release. All nova-powervm development done openly during the release. Initial third-party contributions made. Added new capabilities: * Cold Migration / Rebuild / Resize * Scalability testing * Basic VNC Console * IBM i VMs * Scale & Resiliency testing * July 2016: CI running against all Nova patch sets. Not voting (due to Nova core team guidance) but logs still published to log server. * October 2016: nova-powervm driver updated for Newton release. Updated for: * SR-IOV via PowerVM vNIC * Linux Bridge / OVS * Enhancements to VNC console * Integration with OpenStack Ansible (outside nova-powervm) * October 2016: `First in-tree change set`_ proposed for compute driver spawn/destroy. * November 2016: PowerVMLiveMigrateData object introduced in-tree (Ocata). * January 2017: pypowervm dependency introduced in requirements project (Ocata). * August 2017: Pike Release - `Phase 1`_ implemented including * Full flavor spawn and destroy * Power on/off and reboot * VNC console support * SSP ephemeral disk support .. _`First commit`: https://github.com/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/095e1c183baf4f9083d6b0d363818be21f64f992 .. _`First in-tree change set`: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/391288/ .. _`Phase 1`: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/powervm-nova-compute-driver .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Ocata - Introduced * - Pike - Phase 1 implemented * - Ocata - Phase 2 proposed

commit_message:
Add guru meditation report for ironic

Oslo_reports enables OpenStack projects to dump Guru Meditation
Reports with useful debugging information to files or stderr.
So we introduce it into ironic.

Change-Id: Iad8b800de202a127df81c5dc08a75c0b9b517951
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/36/350736/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright (c) 2014 OpenStack Foundation Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Guru Meditation Reports ======================= Ironic contains a mechanism whereby developers and system administrators can generate a report about the state of a running Ironic executable. This report is called a *Guru Meditation Report* (*GMR* for short). Generating a GMR ---------------- A *GMR* can be generated by sending the *USR2* signal to any Ironic process with support (see below). The *GMR* will then be outputted as standard error for that particular process. For example, suppose that ``Ironic-api`` has process id ``8675``, and was run with ``2>/var/log/ironic/ironic-api-err.log``. Then, ``kill -USR2 8675`` will trigger the Guru Meditation report to be printed to ``/var/log/ironic/ironic-api-err.log``. Structure of a GMR ------------------ The *GMR* is designed to be extensible; any particular executable may add its own sections. However, the base *GMR* consists of several sections: Package Shows information about the package to which this process belongs, including version informations. Threads Shows stack traces and thread ids for each of the threads within this process. Green Threads Shows stack traces for each of the green threads within this process (green threads don't have thread ids). Configuration Lists all the configuration options currently accessible via the CONF object for the current process. Adding Support for GMRs to New Executables ------------------------------------------ Adding support for a *GMR* to a given executable is fairly easy. First import the module: .. code-block:: python from oslo_reports import guru_meditation_report as gmr from ironic import version Then, register any additional sections (optional): .. code-block:: python TextGuruMeditation.register_section('Some Special Section', some_section_generator) Finally (under main), before running the "main loop" of the executable (usually ``service.server(server)`` or something similar), register the *GMR* hook: .. code-block:: python TextGuruMeditation.setup_autorun(version) Extending the GMR ----------------- As mentioned above, additional sections can be added to the GMR for a particular executable. For more information, see the inline documentation under :mod:`oslo.reports`

commit_message:
Pass through oslo.context handled params in RequestContext

Most of the params in RequestContext.__init__() have
already been handled by oslo.context. So we don't need
to handle them one by one in ironic. We can gain many
benifits by doing this

If we add some new properties to oslo.context, such as
"is_admin_project" in olo.context 2.6.0, we don't need
to update ironic to reflect the updates. And we can
avoid compatibility problems as well.

And also, dims has pointed out this in his comment in
the code. "roles" should be passed to __init__() instead
of setting it in ironic once the minimum version of
oslo.context is updated. "roles" was added to oslo.context
in 2.2.0, and now the minimum version is 2.4.0. So we
can do it and remove the comment now.

It is the same to the other oslo handled properties.

And BTW, we should call super.to_dict() in RequestContext.to_dict()

Change-Id: I57ffa3aadcd8f6d0f369244b8862d7423facc527
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/58/345758/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, domain_id=None, is_public_api=False, show_password=True, **kwargs): super(RequestContext, self).__init__(**kwargs) self.is_public_api = is_public_api values = super(RequestContext, self).to_dict() values.update({'domain_id': self.domain_id, 'is_public_api': self.is_public_api}) return values
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, auth_token=None, domain_id=None, domain_name=None, user=None, tenant=None, is_admin=False, is_public_api=False, read_only=False, show_deleted=False, request_id=None, roles=None, show_password=True, overwrite=True): :param auth_token: The authentication token of the current request. :param domain_name: The name of the domain. :param user: The name of the user. :param tenant: The name of the tenant. :param is_admin: Indicates if the request context is an administrator context. :param read_only: unused flag for Ironic. :param show_deleted: unused flag for Ironic. :param request_id: The UUID of the request. :param roles: List of user's roles if any. :param overwrite: Set to False to ensure that the greenthread local copy of the index is not overwritten. super(RequestContext, self).__init__(auth_token=auth_token, user=user, tenant=tenant, is_admin=is_admin, read_only=read_only, show_deleted=show_deleted, request_id=request_id, overwrite=overwrite) self.is_public_api = is_public_api self.domain_name = domain_name # NOTE(dims): roles was added in context.RequestContext recently. # we should pass roles in __init__ above instead of setting the # value here once the minimum version of oslo.context is updated. self.roles = roles or [] return {'auth_token': self.auth_token, 'user': self.user, 'tenant': self.tenant, 'is_admin': self.is_admin, 'read_only': self.read_only, 'show_deleted': self.show_deleted, 'request_id': self.request_id, 'domain_id': self.domain_id, 'roles': self.roles, 'domain_name': self.domain_name, 'is_public_api': self.is_public_api}

commit_message:
Add port deletion on termination of server

APIImpact

Change-Id: I3d6989f694c7774fdebf77bdc0c23727550985f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/97/416997/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Port Deletion on Server Termination =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/port-deletion-on-termination This will provide a mechanism for the user to define what nova should do with pre-created ports when the server is terminated. Problem description =================== If a user boots a server with pre-created ports, nova ignores those ports when the server gets terminated. The user has to manually clean them up, if she wants to completely remove all resources that were associated with the server. Side note: this changed in Kilo with https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1158684 If you really want to clean up, the current behavior is cumbersome due to multiple reasons: * in Horizon, normal members cannot delete ports * in scripts, you need to get the ports, delete the VM, wait until the VM is deleted, delete each port Compare this to boot-from-volume, where the user can specify what to do with the boot volume by setting ``delete_on_terminate``. Use Cases --------- When the user knows upfront that the resources associated with a server are of no use after the server has been terminated, she can express the desired deletion during server boot. This makes things much easier after termination, as no additional cleanup is necessary. Proposed change =============== When booting a server with a pre-created port, the user can specify a property ``shutdown`` (on the commandline) or ``delete_on_termination`` (in the API), analogous to what can be done for boot-from-volume. We could pick different names for the properties, this proposal is for the sake of consistency. The default is ``preserve`` and ``false``, respectively. This way, the behavior remains unchanged for users who don't care about this. Example using the nova CLI (boot-from-volume also included as a reference here) .. code-block:: console $ nova boot \ --flavor myFlavor \ --block-device id=image-uuid,source=image,dest=volume,shutdown=remove \ --nic port-id=port-uuid,shutdown=remove \ myserver Possible values for ``shutdown`` are ``preserve`` and ``remove``. Alternatives ------------ * Not using pre-created ports * Finding a different way to let the user specify what to do with pre-created ports on termination Data model impact ----------------- The NetworkRequest object (and associated table) will gain a boolean attribute, named ``delete_on_termination``. The VIF representation already has a boolean ``preserve_on_delete``, which is currently set to ``true`` for all pre-created devices. This will be set conditionally based on user input. REST API impact --------------- The server create API gains a new boolean parameter in the "network" data dict, named ``delete_on_termination``, for each virtual interface. In terms of the Nova client this would be visible as a new supported key against the ``--nic`` flag. e.g. .. code-block:: console nova boot --nic port-id=UUID,shutdown=remove Example json data for using with the API .. code-block:: json { "server": { "flavorRef": "2", "name": "myserver", "imageRef": "", "block_device_mapping_v2": [ { "uuid": "image-uuid", "source_type": "image", "destination_type": "volume", "delete_on_termination": true } ], "networks": [ { "port": "port-uuid", "delete_on_termination": true } ] } }' This will require a new API microversion. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The new properties on CLIs and API are optional. The default stay the same as of now: pre-created ports are not deleted if the user didn't specify otherwise. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <None> Other contributors: <None> Work items ---------- * Define new attribute for NetworkRequest object * Define new parameters for network requests in REST API(s) * Set ``preserve_on_delete`` for VIF representation in Nova according to API input * Modify the Nova client to allow the extra parameter to be provided * Modify the OpenStack client to allow the extra parameter to be provided Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== The API documentation needs to be updated to list the new ``delete_on_termination`` parameter that is allowed against network devices. Maybe also useful (as also mentioned in https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1158684) would be a new section in the documentation about creating a server with pre-created ports. The pre-Kilo behavior of deleting ports on VM termination wasn't documented, the change in the above bug also didn't add any documentation. This is probably a good opportunity to add some documentation around that. References ========== * Bug about deleting pre-created ports on VM termination: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1158684 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

commit_message:
Be explicit with availability zones on citycloud

The nodepool logic of picking an az if none is given is problematic on
citycloud because they have a nova-local az that we shouldn't use. Be
explicit about which zones to use.

Change-Id: I90205149c2bf0f3a68c7f7d5252567714a5e4c31

commit_message:
Sort out ironic/nova/*

Currently no tests are in-place to test the code in ironic/nova/*
In particular ironic/nova/compute/manager.py

For example a patch to remove the directory ironic/nova/
passed all Jenkins testing:
https://review.openstack.org/191191

Change-Id: I6d43108bbd5fe34ca03e3a73c75ce60c4f9fed3a
Closes-Bug:#1464769

deleted_lines: # coding=utf-8 # # Copyright 2014 Red Hat, Inc. # Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Short term workaround for friction in the Nova compute manager with Ironic. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ironic-nova-friction contains current design work. The goal here is to generalise the areas where n-c talking to a clustered hypervisor has issues, and long term fold them into the main ComputeManager. """ from nova.compute import manager import nova.context from oslo_concurrency import lockutils CCM_SEMAPHORE = 'clustered_compute_manager' class ClusteredComputeManager(manager.ComputeManager): def init_host(self): """Initialization for a clustered compute service.""" self.driver.init_host(host=self.host) # Not used currently. # context = nova.context.get_admin_context() # instances = instance_obj.InstanceList.get_by_host( # context, self.host, expected_attrs=['info_cache']) # defer_iptables_apply is moot for clusters - no local iptables # if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: # self.driver.filter_defer_apply_on() self.init_virt_events() # try: # evacuation is moot for a clustered hypervisor # # checking that instance was not already evacuated to other host # self._destroy_evacuated_instances(context) # Don't run _init_instance until we solve the partitioning problem # - with N n-cpu's all claiming the same hostname, running # _init_instance here would lead to race conditions where each runs # _init_instance concurrently. # for instance in instances: # self._init_instance(context, instance) # finally: # defer_iptables_apply is moot for clusters - no local iptables # if CONF.defer_iptables_apply: # self.driver.filter_defer_apply_off() def pre_start_hook(self): """Update our available resources After the service is initialized, but before we fully bring the service up by listening on RPC queues, make sure to update our available resources (and indirectly our available nodes). """ # This is an optimisation to immediately advertise resources but # the periodic task will update them eventually anyway, so ignore # errors as they may be transient (e.g. the scheduler isn't # available...). XXX(lifeless) this applies to all ComputeManagers # and once I feature freeze is over we should push that to nova # directly. try: self.update_available_resource(nova.context.get_admin_context()) except Exception: pass @lockutils.synchronized(CCM_SEMAPHORE, 'ironic-') def _update_resources(self): """Update our resources Updates the resources while protecting against a race on self._resource_tracker_dict. """ self.update_available_resource(nova.context.get_admin_context()) def terminate_instance(self, context, instance, bdms, reservations): """Terminate an instance on a node. We override this method and force a post-termination update to Nova's resources. This avoids having to wait for a Nova periodic task tick before nodes can be reused. """ super(ClusteredComputeManager, self).terminate_instance(context, instance, bdms, reservations) self._update_resources()

commit_message:
Prevent non-check changes, add infra pipelines

Change the pipeline config to include invalid requirements for all
non-check pipelines so that we can keep project-pipeline configs but not
have any changes be enqueued in them. This should allow running v2 and
v3 side by side.

Add infra- versions of gate and post so that we can continue to use v3
to gate zuul, zuul-jobs, openstack-zuul-jobs and project-config.

Change-Id: I084b819ea0a4b67f36df61ccb3bfd6963cc3940d

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Lenovo # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Lenovo XClarity Administrator Management Driver """ from ironic.common import boot_devices from ironic.common import exception from ironic.common.i18n import _ from ironic.conductor import task_manager from ironic.drivers import base from ironic.drivers.modules.lxca import common as lxca_common from ironic.drivers.modules.lxca import lxca_service from oslo_log import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) _BOOT_DEVICES_MAP = { boot_devices.DISK: 'Hard Disk 0', boot_devices.PXE: 'PXE Network', boot_devices.CDROM: 'CD/DVD Rom', } class LXCAManagement(base.ManagementInterface): """do the management by xClarity Driver""" def get_properties(self): return lxca_common.LXCA_COMMON_PROPERTIES def validate(self, task): return lxca_common.parse_driver_info(task.node) def get_supported_boot_devices(self, task): """Get a list of the supported boot devices. :param task: a task from TaskManager. :returns: A list with the supported boot devices defined in :mod:`ironic.common.boot_devices`. """ return list(_BOOT_DEVICES_MAP.keys()) @task_manager.require_exclusive_lock def set_boot_device(self, task, device, persistent=False): """set boot device""" try: boot_device = _BOOT_DEVICES_MAP[device] except KeyError: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue(_( "Invalid boot device %s specified.") % device) xclarityObject = lxca_service.get_lxca_object(None, task.node) xclarityObject.set_boot_device(boot_device, persistent) def get_boot_device(self, task): xclarityObject = lxca_service.get_lxca_object(None, task.node) boot_devices = eval(xclarityObject.get_boot_device()) permanent_ret = {} for index in range(len(boot_devices)): tmp_device = boot_devices[index] if tmp_device['bootType'] == 'SingleUse': current_boot_order = eval( tmp_device['currentBootOrderDevices']) if current_boot_order and "None" not in current_boot_order: return {'boot_device': current_boot_order[0], 'persistent': False} else: return {'boot_device': "unknown", 'persistent': False} elif tmp_device['bootType'] == 'Permanent': current_boot_order = eval( tmp_device['currentBootOrderDevices']) if current_boot_order: permanent_ret['boot_device'] = current_boot_order[0] permanent_ret['persistent'] = True # if here, then permanent return permanent_ret def get_sensors_data(self, task): raise NotImplementedError()

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================== Lenovo XClarity driver ==================== This blueprint proposes adding new driver that supports deployment of Lenovo XClarity managed Systemx Flex/X6/M5 serie servers. In this blueprint servers, nodes are used interchangeably that denotes Flex/X6/M5 serie servers. Problem description =================== Current Ironic drivers require IPMI protocol to be enabled on all Systemx Flex/X6/M5 serie servers in order to manage power and other operations. Sometime, for security reasons IPMI protocol is disabled by administrators. From Flex/X6/M5 serie servers, these nodes should be firstly managed by XClarity administrator tool and be associated with a UUID, and be operated by XClarity. No knowledge of IPMI account of individual node need to be known by users. Instead of using IPMI protocol, this blueprint proposes new driver to manage Systemx Flex/X6/M5 serie servers using XClarity RESTful API. Proposed change =============== New power, deployment and management interfaces will be added as part of lenovo_xclarity driver. This driver uses RESTful API for communicating with XClarity. This driver uses * lenovo.XClarityDeploy for PXE-less deployment operations * lenovo.XClarityPower for power operations * lenovo.XClarityManagement for management interface operations XClarity RESTful API provides can perform various operations, like controlling the power of nodes, retrieving firmware version and FoD(Feature on demand) enablement information, and deploy OS without PXE server, etc. Physical and Logical entities in XClarity are represented as XClarityObject. * Power management: Controlling the power is as simple as to modifying the 'power_state' property of the XClarityObject with the given UUID representing the target node. * Management Interface: This interface allows the user to get and set the boot-order on Systemx Flex/X6/M5 servers. This interface reads and updates XClarityObject with the given UUID and persist the information accordingly. get_sensor_data() implementation is not in scope of this spec. * Deploy Interface: This interface allows the user to deploy pre-installed operating system image in XClarity to target node. Deploy OS into XClarity managed node requiring additional parameters as following: * selected_image: The ID of the pre-installed image in XClarity that users are going to deploy * selected_mac: The MAC address of a NIC which is communicating with XCarltiy if multiple NICs are installed on a server. * storage_device: On which local storage device will the OS be installed. Alternatives ------------ Data model impact ----------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- The following driver_info fields are required while enrolling node into ironic: * xclarity_ip: XClarity hostname/ip-address * xclarity_username: User account with admin role * xclarity_password: User account password * xclarity_protocol: protocol used by xClarity connection, default is https. * node_uuid: A unique ID that is associated with a node in XClarity. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * Add new lenovo_xclarity driver, extending power, deploy and management interface APIs. * Writing and unit-test cases for lenovo_xclarity driver. * Writing configuration documents. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Unit-tests will be implemented for new lenovo_xclarity driver. tempest test suite will be updated to cover the lenovo_xclarity driver. Continuous integration (CI) support will be added for Lenovo Systemx Flex/X6/M5 serie series servers. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== This driver will not break any compatibility with either on REST API or RPC APIs. Documentation Impact ==================== * Writing configuration documents. * Updating Ironic documentation section _`Enabling Drivers`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/drivers.html with lenovo_xclarity driver related instructions. References ========== _`Supported Systemx servers`:http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/technotes/tips1200.pdf

commit_message:
Generate uuids, instead of defaulting

Defaulting uuids can lead to IntegrityErrors, for example when
creating two nodes in the same test. It's better to generate
an uuid while creating the node in the db instead

Change-Id: Idb1f9e73015c528fff1f1815fe72f8d65c7117c3

commit_message:
Extend abort action to deploy_wait

Support using `abort` action to stop deploy_wait states and move
to deploy_fail.
Add a new transition from deploy_wait to deploy_fail use
`abort` action
Bump API to 1.15.

Closes-Bug: #1498251
Change-Id: I53d1391f707c00804888f2662de3f9dc551e38a7

commit_message:
Switch default partition type to gpt

Systems with >2TB 'disks' are becoming more commonplace on servers
with embedded raid arrays etc. Switch default partition type to gpt
from msdos when we find ourselves with a larger disk.

Change-Id: If033412e2a5f0223bc5aeaa6cb5dd3287b6431c0
Partial-Bug: #1298362

commit_message:
Do not checked from remote branch

In project requirements change we checkout a remote branch.
However with zuulv3 repos won't have a remote set, they are pushed
on the server with the right branch already. So using a local
branch instead.

Change-Id: I306564148116269c1f8650670a116e72733f7b0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/75/508875/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: run_command("git checkout %s" % branch)
deleted_lines: run_command("git remote update") run_command("git checkout remotes/origin/%s" % branch)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-30 02:51:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/2f14584c84530cfaa08c5f8fa74abe1c20d69096', 'message': "Support trusted boot with iPXE

commit_message:
Support trusted boot using iPXE

With this patch, Ironic can boot nodes with trusted
boot using iPXE.

As iPXE didn't support multiple loading,
which is necessary to trusted boot. So trusted boot using
iPXE is actually regress to reuse PXE to deliver kernel and ramdisk.

The work flow is like this:
1. Ironic generates a special ipxe script file for nodes which
enable trusted boot.
2. These nodes boot into trusted_boot.ipxe and load pxelinux.0.
3. pxelinux.0 will directly fetch corresponding pxe config
   and load kernel and ramdisk.

It is recommended to enable trusted boot using PXE, but
if users are already using iPXE, it is still possible to
enable trusted boot for some nodes without change all to using PXE.

Implements blueprint bare-metal-trust-using-intel-txt

Change-Id: I7eb817b18a31a5b717fa33c4394fbfd51abab25a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/78/207278/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add exception log when migrate action failed

As of now we can not know what was happend when migrate action
failed critically.
This patch adds exception log when migrate action failed critically.

Change-Id: I54d0bc54ee1df6f13754771775c58255f53f5008

commit_message:
libvirt: fix operation when ceph is disabled

The movement of the ceph secret logic into the start script introduced
a bug that was missed in review when ceph is disabled, this PS
restores expected operation.

Closes-Bug: #1720061

Change-Id: Ie373ff94814ea396832a83101c885ebf92b6f8cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/97/508197/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "x${LIBVIRT_CEPH_ENABLED}" == "xTrue" ] ; then libvirtd --listen & LIBVIRT_SECRET_DEF=$(mktemp --suffix .xml) function cleanup { rm -f ${LIBVIRT_SECRET_DEF} } trap cleanup EXIT # Wait for the libvirtd is up TIMEOUT=60 while [[ ! -f /var/run/libvirtd.pid ]]; do if [[ ${TIMEOUT} -gt 0 ]]; then let TIMEOUT-=1 sleep 1 else echo "ERROR: libvirt did not start in time (pid file missing)" exit 1 fi done # Even though we see the pid file the socket immediately (this is # needed for virsh) TIMEOUT=10 while [[ ! -e /var/run/libvirt/libvirt-sock ]]; do if [[ ${TIMEOUT} -gt 0 ]]; then let TIMEOUT-=1 sleep 1 else echo "ERROR: libvirt did not start in time (socket missing)" exit 1 fi done if [ -z "${LIBVIRT_CEPH_SECRET_UUID}" ] ; then echo "ERROR: No libvirt Secret UUID Supplied" if [ -z "${CEPH_CINDER_KEYRING}" ] ; then CEPH_CINDER_KEYRING=$(sed -n 's/^[[:space:]]*key[[:blank:]]\+=[[:space:]]\(.*\)/\1/p' /etc/ceph/ceph.client.${CEPH_CINDER_USER}.keyring) cat > ${LIBVIRT_SECRET_DEF} <<EOF virsh secret-define --file ${LIBVIRT_SECRET_DEF} virsh secret-set-value --secret "${LIBVIRT_CEPH_SECRET_UUID}" --base64 "${CEPH_CINDER_KEYRING}" # rejoin libvirtd wait else exec libvirtd --listen fi

commit_message:
[POC]Add support to boot WinPE

Many users are used to managing their machines by using WinPE.
They have many tools work well in the WinPE system which
make life easier. So why not provide the functionality in Ironic?

In this POC, Ironic simply boot a WinPE(iso) on the target host through PXE.
That's all for Ironic. Then Admin can do whatever he want by using WinPE.

Change-Id: Ic5094df0378039db7efbc5f8760e4d4673552a06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/82/220882/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: label boot_winpe kernel memdisk append initrd={{ pxe_options.deployment_ari_path}} iso raw

commit_message:
openstack_auth.backend: Error getting domain scoped token during login

Examining the Horizon Keystone driver, we see that on user login, it
will attempt to get both a domain scoped token and project scoped token.
A domain scoped token is needed since for Multi-domain deployments there
are RBAC domain-specific policy rules. However since ours is a single
domain deployment we ONLY exercise the project scoped token, and
therefore the project based RBAC rules.

There is however a bug here, where it shouldn't even be trying to get a
domain scoped token if multi-domain has been disabled in Horizon
(OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT in local_settings)

Since this option is disabled, there is no way to assign a role for this
logon user on any domain so domain scoped token calls will always fail,
not to mention being a totally redundant call out to Keystone.

Change-Id: I311f3d1f1252c8658e778b2abad274510639a09b
Closes-Bug: #1641638
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth refs/changes/32/397332/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Only attempt to retrieve a domain scoped token, if # OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT is enabled, otherwise # such a toekn auth call to Identity would be redundant. domain_support = getattr(settings, 'OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT', False) if (domain_support and utils.get_keystone_version() >= 3 and 'user_domain_name' in kwargs):

commit_message:
Ironic should use its own context

Currently ironic conductor use context from oslo_context directly.
The log context format string fails to get the user_name and
project_name parameter from context due to the changes to use
oslo_log. This patch aims to build the correct context structure
for ironic.

Change-Id: I0627c66957c1064d69c953f59f401739c6e4385f
Closes-bug: 1456428

commit_message:
Build requirements in parallel

To help facilitate building quickly in the gate, we can safely build the
requirement wheels in parallel.

This reduces a 22 minute build to a 6 minute build on my hardware.

Change-Id: I76335d6244e9b46adb0266423423a52e9f5acef7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/loci refs/changes/89/508789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mkdir /tmp/download/ # NOTE(SamYaple): Download all deps in parallel cat /upper-constraints.txt | xargs -n1 -P20 pip install -q --download /tmp/download # NOTE(SamYaple): Build all deps in parallel. This is safe because we are # constrained on the version and we are building with --no-deps cat /upper-constraints.txt | xargs -n1 -P20 pip wheel --no-index --find-links /tmp/download --wheel-dir / -c /upper-constraints.txt --no-deps # NOTE(SamYaple): Handle packages not in global-requirements additional_packages=(bindep==2.5.0 uwsgi) echo "${additional_packages[@]}" | xargs -n1 -P20 pip wheel --wheel-dir / -c /upper-constraints.txt

commit_message:
Add support to fetch_wheels for saved images

Change-Id: I622d75d3832c2c5312d6dbdb6c432100484dce17
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/loci refs/changes/17/508717/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def main(): if 'WHEELS' in os.environ: wheels = os.environ['WHEELS'] else: with open('/opt/loci/wheels', 'ro') as f: wheels = f.read() if wheels.startswith('/'): with open(wheels, 'r') as f: data = f.read() elif wheels.startswith('http'): data = get_wheels(wheels) else: registry, image, tag = parse_image(wheels) kwargs = dict() if registry: kwargs.update({'registry': registry}) else: kwargs.update({'token': get_token(image)}) data = get_blob(image, tag, **kwargs) if 'WHEELS_DEST' in os.environ: dest = os.environ['WHEELS_DEST'] else: with open('/opt/loci/wheels', 'w') as f: f.write(wheels) dest = '/tmp/wheels.tar.gz' with open(dest, 'wb') as f: f.write(data) if __name__ == '__main__': main()
deleted_lines: if 'WHEELS' in os.environ: wheels = os.environ['WHEELS'] else: with open('/opt/loci/wheels', 'ro') as f: wheels = f.read() with open('/opt/loci/wheels', 'w+') as f: f.write(wheels) if wheels.startswith('http'): data = get_wheels(wheels) else: registry, image, tag = parse_image(wheels) kwargs = dict() if registry: kwargs.update({'registry': registry}) else: kwargs.update({'token': get_token(image)}) print(kwargs) data = get_blob(image, tag, **kwargs) with open('/tmp/wheels.tar.gz', 'wb') as f: f.write(data)

Add requirements support to generic dockerfile

If the bindep changes upstream merge, then we can collapse alot of this
into bindep.txt file as well. For now, manually declaring is fine.

commit_message:
Move to single dockerfile

Build-args will control FROM args. Centos, Ubuntu, and Debian will
remain officially supported.

This will completely remove the logic from Dockerfile and put it in the
scripts control which is the direction we have been headed for a while.

Change-Id: I8e0745b50e6c141da5ca8f57b415ae206dad5ab4

commit_message:
[devstack]Remove cache dirs

Remove the creation and use of all the AUTH_CACHE directories
as the need for the cache directories by keystone is deprecated.

Change-Id: I6d1656ac7e7a008671adabac824eaf65b41d917d
Closes-bug: #1721027

commit_message:
Request traits in Nova

This blueprint aims at leveraging traits to standardize the way
of requesting qualitative resources in Nova.

Blueprint request-traits-in-nova

Change-Id: Iebeaa0db693ed216a31464eb91897ab215fe2651
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/97/468797/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Request traits in Nova ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/request-traits-in-nova This blueprint aims at leveraging traits to standardize the way of requesting qualitative resources in Nova. Problem description =================== Cloud administrators currently have to deal with free-formed flavor extra_specs and image metadata in order to specify capabilities in a launch request. Without standardization of capabilities, there is no possibility of interoperable OpenStack clouds. We have introduced traits to manage the qualitative parts of ResourceProviders in Placement[1]. Administrators should be able to create flavors associated with traits. while booting a instance, Nova API should be aware of the presence of traits and process them gracefully, before making request to a generic scheduler. Use Cases --------- For administrative users: * Allow nova-api to validate capabilities for administrators when create a flavor. For end users: * Allow nova to translate traits specified in flavor or image from a boot request. * Fail fast in nova-api when a requested trait doesn't exist or isn't valid in the cloud. For developers: * Standardize how to request traits through request spec. * Decouple nova-specific traits handling out of scheduler. Proposed change =============== We propose to modify create flavor api to accept and validate associated traits. And collect traits from flavor and image metadata in a boot request to generate the qualitative part to the generic scheduler in request spec. The proposed change adds the following features to Nova: Traits management in flavors ---------------------------------- The flavor would be associated with traits by a many-to-many relationship, and is persisted to API database. Create flavor API will be modified to allow administrators to specify traits. Validation of traits from Placement API is also need before saving flavors to database. Traits management in image metadata ----------------------------------------- When processing a boot request in nova-api, parse `ImageMeta` object to get associated traits, this could make sure we handle traits in a consistent way with flavors. Traits validation in Nova ------------------------------- Traits validation happens in flavor creation operations as well as when a boot request is received by nova-api. The validation implies following checks: 1. Validate traits by querying Placement API. 2. Report error when a trait string could not be found in Placement. Build up qualitative part of request in the request_spec object --------------------------------------------------------------- The major goal of this spec is to follow the concept of "generic scheduler" and approach the final separation from scheduler, at least in the qualitative part. A collection of valid traits can be collected from flavor and image metadata, and be set into a new field in the request_spec. Then the scheduler can make decisions based on traits specifications in request_spec. Alternatives ------------ We can continue to use flavor extra_specs and image metadata without standard traits, and let scheduler handle them directly. But it will block future attempts to implement interoperable OpenStack clouds and generic schedulers. Considering traits preference, we currently have some ideas about "Where to specify preferences" and "How to order preferences", but they may not be settled in this spec. Data model impact ----------------- For the API database schema, the following table should be created to persist capabilities specified in flavor:: CREATE TABLE flavor_trait ( flavor_id INT NOT NULL, trait_name VARCHAR(200) NOT NULL ); We will also need to store the set of traits that the user requested in the `instance_extra` table. Flavors can change over time and even be deleted so we need to ensure that any information we used in the initial request is saved so that on things like live migration we can be sure to apply the same placement conditions. REST API impact --------------- TODO. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Lei Zhang <lei.a.zhang@intel.com> Other contributors: Alex Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com> Ed Leafe <ed@leafe.com> cyx1231st <yingxin.cheng@intel.com> Work Items ---------- TODO. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit tests and functional tests for creating flavors, image metadata, and building up requests shall be added. Documentation Impact ==================== The new API microversion will have to be documented, as well as the user guides for specifying traits in flavor. References ========== [1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/pike/approved/resource-provider-traits.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

Dell EMC PS: Report total volumes on the backend

Adds support to report total_volumes in the volume stats. Total number
of volumes on the storage backend can be used in custom driver
filter functions.

commit_message:
Switch from ipv6-icmp to icmpv6

The firewall module changed the name of the ipv6-icmp protocol to
icmpv6[1].  This is a breaking change, but it seems that ip6tables
itself actually changed its accepted values for this at some point
so I guess we should use the new name anyway.

1: https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-firewall/commit/41fb8205b68aec8a3683e1b4f53ec9de2246d504

Change-Id: I58b5063649793af86bae360d412c3e85bb3cadd4
Closes-Bug: 1720918
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/41/509041/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'proto' => 'icmpv6',

commit_message:
Replace test.attr with decorators.attr

Function 'tempest.test.attr()' has moved to 'tempest.lib.decorators
.attr()' in Pike and will be removed in a future version[1].
This patch replaces the 'tempest.test.attr()' with the 'tempest.lib
.decorators.attr().'

[1] Iaafbb112b6eee458089cc49918359a8a8d0485e2

Change-Id: Icb5cfdf5af3c4db34ffde518346e75568f5c68d1

subject: Adopt python-openstacksdk into shade project
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-06 20:53:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/d4333b3745feb73e93e50488bad71e57fe97d686', 'message': "Adopt python-openstacksdk into shade project

While shade has been focused on a high-level python interface to
OpenStack that hides vendor differences, python-openstacksdk has been
focused on exposing the REST APIs as they are in python. The two tasks
share enough underpinnings that having two separate teams work on two
separate efforts is not an efficient use of resources these days.

python-openstacksdk by nature of its name sounds to people like it's an
official project but has never been made one which causes confusion.

As a result of shade and openstacksdk having been parallel efforts and
the different teams having slightly divergent points of view on how to
structure abstractions, openstacksdk is sadly unusable by shade in its
current form. Such divergence at this point doesn't improve the world for
anyone.

Bring the python-openstacksdk repo officially into the shade project.
The intent will be to evolve both projects into sharing a holistic
approach to consuming OpenStack APIs with openstacksdk as the lower
level and shade as a business-logic layer on top of it. This will mean
an amount of breaking changes to openstacksdk, although as it has not
yet released a 1.0 that is less bad than it otherwise could be. As
python-openstackclient uses python-openstacksdk for neutron
interactions, great care must be taken to not break
python-openstackclient in the process.

The existing shade-core will be merged with members of the
python-openstacksdk-core team who desire to continue.

Discussions of merging or consolidating repositories will follow at a
later date if they prove to be valuable but are not being proposed at
this time.

Change-Id: Ibc0e6200121a536dc7072af9049a68eac8bb28e9

commit_message:
Adopt python-openstacksdk into shade project

While shade has been focused on a high-level python interface to
OpenStack that hides vendor differences, python-openstacksdk has been
focused on exposing the REST APIs as they are in python. The two tasks
share enough underpinnings that having two separate teams work on two
separate efforts is not an efficient use of resources these days.

python-openstacksdk by nature of its name sounds to people like it's an
official project but has never been made one which causes confusion.

As a result of shade and openstacksdk having been parallel efforts and
the different teams having slightly divergent points of view on how to
structure abstractions, openstacksdk is sadly unusable by shade in its
current form. Such divergence at this point doesn't improve the world for
anyone.

Bring the python-openstacksdk repo officially into the shade project.
The intent will be to evolve both projects into sharing a holistic
approach to consuming OpenStack APIs with openstacksdk as the lower
level and shade as a business-logic layer on top of it. This will mean
an amount of breaking changes to openstacksdk, although as it has not
yet released a 1.0 that is less bad than it otherwise could be. As
python-openstackclient uses python-openstacksdk for neutron
interactions, great care must be taken to not break
python-openstackclient in the process.

The existing shade-core will be merged with members of the
python-openstacksdk-core team who desire to continue.

Discussions of merging or consolidating repositories will follow at a
later date if they prove to be valuable but are not being proposed at
this time.

Change-Id: Ibc0e6200121a536dc7072af9049a68eac8bb28e9

commit_message:
Set BUILD_TIMEOUT for ironic grenade jobs

After migration to zuulv3 we found that timeout set in the job
is not applied to grenade runs.
This patch export BUILD_TIMEOUT directly from job.

Change-Id: I7a297af4461cf25227f1cff281e84e728baf90d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs refs/changes/82/508882/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export BUILD_TIMEOUT=180
